definition: lit. house made of gold/fig. luxurious residence
gold/chemical element Au/generic term for lustrous and ductile metals/money/golden/highly respected/one of the eight categories of ancient musical instruments 八音[ba1 yin1]
lit. in books are sumptuous houses and graceful ladies (proverb)/fig. be diligent in your studies, success and glory will follow
pinyin: shu1 zhong1 zi4 you3 huang2 jin1 wu1 , shu1 zhong1 zi4 you3 yan2 ru2 yu4
containing_words.word: 书中自有黄金屋，书中自有颜如玉

sentences.english: A book holds a house of gold.
sentences.chinese: 书中自有黄金屋可以翻成。

sentences.english: Don't need to build high towers for cozy living; There are houses of gold in books.
sentences.chinese: 安居不用架高楼，书中自有黄金屋。

definition: lit. opening a book is profitable (idiom); the benefits of education
to read a book/to study/to attend school
see 行萬里路，讀萬卷書|行万里路，读万卷书[xing2 wan4 li3 lu4 , du2 wan4 juan4 shu1]
pinyin: du2 wan4 juan4 shu1 , xing2 wan4 li3 lu4

definition: lit. with his head attached to a beam and stabbing his thigh with an awl (idiom)/fig. to study assiduously and tirelessly
pinyin: tou2 xuan2 liang2 , zhui1 ci4 gu3

definition: to read extensively and thoroughly/nonstandard pronunciation of a Chinese character, e.g. the reading [hao4] in 愛好|爱好[ai4 hao4] rather than the usual [hao3]
sea of learning, no horizon (idiom); no limits to what one still has to learn/ars longa, vita brevis
precious horses and magnificent carriage (idiom); rich family with extravagant lifestyle/ostentatious display of luxury
